content: After a product is launched, it is really affirming if you can see measureable impact. I met with a team to pick key metrics to evaluate our performance. I spent significant time calculating results and iterating with our team about data gaps or process changes that affected data qualitty.

I performed calculations in Power BI with the intent to move the story to a more carefully crafted and visually appealing pdf. I started creating the pdf in Figma wiht the option to move to Adobe InDesign if the project grew large for ease of use.
I created this 'Scorecard Lifecycle' page as a process overview graphic to emphasize the cyclic nature of the product and serve as a guide in the story of the product's impact.

I decided to create this graphic to narrate the story. I knew we had a cycle and wrote down key terms to find a good fit. In my first draft, I was more heavy on the technical side, including a technical term on the scorecard phase. I adjusted with this feedback and found it was a better fit. Adding an enttry and exit way was also a stakeholder request.
I created an overview of our key metrics page to read main takeways before diving into more details.

In the left two columns, I wanted to unify the direction of the metrics for an easy read. I mean because we would like to drive some metrics down and others up. But if you are not familiar with the metric definition, you would not know what a positive change is. So first on the left, to handle this, I included significant improvement and percent improvement. Then continueing to read from left tto right, each metric is defined, and the raw numbers used in the improvement calculation are displayed.
